summary: This is an FBI 302 interview report documenting an interview with a Bureau of Prisons Lieutenant regarding standard operating procedures for prisoner counts and rounds at the Metropolitan Correctional Facility (MCC). The interview was conducted in the context of the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death, and the lieutenant states she has no knowledge of counts or rounds not being conducted and did not speak with guards THOMAS and NOEL about the events surrounding Epstein's death.

persons.name: Rebekah Donaleski
persons.context: Present during the interview of the BOP Lieutenant as part of the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: His death at the MCC is the subject of the investigation that prompted this interview.

persons.name: THOMAS
persons.context: A guard at the MCC whom the interviewed lieutenant stated she did not speak with about the events surrounding Epstein's death.

persons.name: NOEL
persons.context: A guard at the MCC whom the interviewed lieutenant stated she did not speak with about the events surrounding Epstein's death.

connections.description: Donaleski, as an AUSA, was involved in the investigation into Epstein's death.

events.title: Interview of BOP Lieutenant
events.description: FBI agents and an AUSA interviewed a Bureau of Prisons Lieutenant regarding MCC procedures and the events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein Death Investigation Interview
events.description: An interview was conducted as part of the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death at the MCC, focusing on standard prison count and round procedures.

locations: New York, New York, United States
keyFacts: The interviewed BOP Lieutenant stated she has no knowledge of prisoner counts or rounds not being conducted at the MCC.
The lieutenant stated she did not speak with guards THOMAS and NOEL about the events surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's death.
The document details the standard, multi-step procedure for conducting official prisoner counts at the MCC, involving two guards and verification with a central control.
Guards are also required to conduct 'rounds' every 30-40 minutes to visually confirm prisoners are alive and in their cells.
The lieutenant commented that 'guards can only do so much with what they are given and that due to staffing sometimes things happen.'
